data.title: Cinema Asia: China
data.meta_description: Films Media Group, an Infobase Learning Company, is the premier source of high-quality academic streaming video and DVDs for schools, colleges, and libraries.
data.text:
Hollywood of the East (00:58)

FREE PREVIEW

Some of China's biggest blockbusters are shot in Hengdian World Studios, the largest film studio in the world. For every Chinese blockbuster, there are hundreds waiting in the wings.

Foreign Market for Chinese Films (00:60)

Only a few of China's films make it abroad, yet the foreign market is crucial for China's film industry. These include China's martial arts films.

China's Oscars (01:17)

China's answer to the Oscars is the Golden Rooster Award, which honors China's most successful directors..

Army of Filmmakers (01:34)

In China today, a growing army of filmmakers is producing a huge variety of films. Most of the films produced by China's talented filmmakers are not seen outside China.

China's Theater Shortage (00:55)

There is an acute shortage of theaters in China. Even when theaters are crowded, films still do not get enough viewers. Revenue from all films in China is one year amounted to only $125 million.

1966 Cultural Revolution (01:02)

In 1966, the Cultural Revolution in China brought the film industry to a stop. Traditional forms of art were destroyed, and movie studios shut down. A new generation of directors emerged.

Beijing Film Studio (01:22)

The spiritual heart of the Chinese film industry is at the Beijing Film Studio. It is here that some of China's most famous directors shot their first film and some of China's most famous movies.

Last Days for Beijing Film Studio (00:57)

The appetite for films in China is larger than the Beijing Film Studio can satisfy. Fewer movies are made here. High rises in the background limit camera angles within the movie lot itself.

Gang of Four: China's Revolution (00:60)

The Cultural Revolution shut down schools and universities. Literature was replaced by readings from Mao's "Little Red Book." Only revolutionary songs could be sung.

Post-Revolutionary Film Industry (01:18)

During the Revolution, only a few films were being made in China. They included recordings of revolutionary operas and ballets, Films began to be made in 1973, and the industry took off in the early 1980s.

Fifth-Generation Filmmakers (02:26)

After the Cultural Revolution, film schools re-opened. Known as the Fifth Generation, this new group kick started the film industry in the 1980s. China's three most famous directors emerge during this period.

Film Director Zhang Yimou (01:16)

Director Zhang Yimou experiments with innovative cinematography and with risky subject matter. He wants to appeal to international audiences, but he may risk censure at home.

Film Theme: Love Story (01:05)

In "The Road Home," Director Zhang Yimou uses a simple love story to capture China's lost innocence.

"Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" (00:51)

Taiwanese director Ang Lee found the key of global blockbuster success with a film that brought new images and a new kind of story to an international audience.

Zhang Yimou's Epic Hero (01:19)

Zhang Yimou's response to Ang Lee's success is "Hero." He combines magical storytelling with his trademark cinematography. Actress Zhang Ziyi talks about the two great directors, Yimou and Lee.

Cinematography/Traditional Painting (00:52)

A film critic describes Zhang Yimou's lake scene as a "form of a Chinese traditional Shoujuan Hua painting."

Film Theme Contradicts Tradition (01:12)

In China, some were critical of the message in Zhang Yimou's "Hero." The storyline is contrary to the Chinese people's historical point of view.

Film Success in Chinese Market (00:58)

The overwhelming success of "Hero" surprised the Chinese film industry. The film grossed $30 million. It showed the immense potential of the Chinese market.

In Search of International Success (00:60)

In their hunger for international success, Chinese filmmakers import talent and learn from abroad. Zhang Yimou follows up "Hero" with ever more elaborate tricks in his films. "House of the Flying Daggers" was an international blockbuster.

Director Chen Kaige (01:13)

Director Chen Kaige, like Zhang Yimou, chases the international film market. His "The Promise" is the most expensive Chinese film to date. He uses actors from Korea and Japan.

Foreign Film Market (00:59)

Top end directors continue to chase the foreign market with kung fu epics. Critics denounce the films for retreating from reality instead of confronting history and reality.

Privatization of Film Studios (01:05)

Spectacular epics and martial arts films put Chinese cinema on international screens. In 1993, China's film studios were privatized. Profits, and not propaganda, ruled.

Chinese Comedy Films (01:27)

Director Feng Xiaogang risks making films about real people, people that Chinese audiences can relate to. His films are contemporary rather than historical; he uses comedy rather than allegory.

Films About Contemporary Chinese Society (02:00)

Among the "Fifth Generation" directors, both Chen Kaige and Zhang Yimou focus on high culture. Later Zhang Yimou moves to commercial subjects. Feng Xiaogang is different; he is very down-to-earth.

Post-Tiananmen Directors (01:01)

A new generation of filmmakers emerges after the Tiananmen protests in 1989. Called the "Sixth Generation" directors, they have their sights set at home. "Beijing Bastards" launches a new wave in Chinese cinema.

New Generation of Chinese Filmmakers (01:03)

The "Sixth Generation" filmmakers shed light on a side of China previously kept hidden away. Government censors keep prohibitive subjects off the screen. New technologies allow young filmmakers to elude government control.

Contemporary Chinese Stories (01:07)

China's "Sixth Generation" movie makers turn out nitty-gritty, everyday, contemporary Chinese stories.

Inspired Young Filmmakers (00:58)

The back alleyways of China supply inspiration for young filmmakers in tight budgets. Feng Xiaogang, on the other hand, wants to appeal to a global audience.

Box Office Records (00:58)

Feng Xiaogang's "A World Without Thieves" set box office records in China, beating "Lord of the Rings." But it did not capture world markets where the big money is.

Historical Epics (01:54)

For his next film, Feng Xiaogang leaped into the realm of historical epics. It is a challenging project for the director.

Underground Filmmakers (01:14)

While Chinese blockbusters fill cinemas throughout the world, hundreds of other Chinese films struggle to find an audience. These are the films of the "Sixth Generation" and of the underground filmmakers.

Everyday Life Depictions Censored (00:57)

Many films of "Sixth Generation" directors are censored for their frank depiction of everyday life.

Sixth Generation Film Directors (01:56)

"Sixth Generation" directors had to choose to make government-controlled propaganda films, or to go independent and underground. They made low-budget films for overseas film festivals.

Film Censorship in China (01:56)

New Chinese directors may be stifling their creativity in order to appease censors. Censors ban films that show sex, drugs, and violence, or that otherwise show China in a bad light. The film "The Blue Kite" was hard hit by censors.

Illegal Film Copying in China (01:21)

In all of China there are only 3000 movie screens. Most film directors rely on DVDs to gain audiences for their films. For actors and performers, illegal copies are a serious problem, as most of their income is taken away.

Film Piracy (00:60)

If filmmakers could attract film goers back into the theaters, they could reduce film piracy.

Beijing Olympics Generation (01:17)

Despite the obstacles over the past 25 years, Chinese cinema has come a long way. A new generation of filmmakers is ready for success. The Beijing Olympics generation is the next revolution in Chinese cinema.

Chinese Mainstream Cinema (00:52)

The newest generation of Chinese filmmakers has a different way of expressing their creative vision. They want to make mainstream movies that influence people. They must learn new skills such as how to distribute their films.

Chinese Film Market: 1.3 Billion (01:02)

Chinese cinema will prosper because the Chinese film market is enormous. There are 1.3 billion people in China today.

Chinese Hearts and Minds (00:53)

A Chinese film director believes his films are not completed until they have touched the hearts and minds of his audience.
